description.plain:
Slick Rick is one of hip hop’s many pioneers who was best known for his abilities in storytelling and iconic eyepatch. In addition to this, he has released a total of 4 albums, all of which charted on the Billboard 200 and collaborated with a multitude of artists in the rap industry.

He was first born in the city of London before relocating to the Bronx when he was 5 years old. Most of his childhood was plagued by the deformity of his left eye which was ultimately caused when a sharp piece of glass struck it at the age of 18 months. To hide this, he donned dark-rimmed eyeglasses while attending local hip-hop shows prior to wearing his eyepatch.

His career in hip-hop began in 1984 when he met Doug E. Fresh and joined his Get Fresh Crew in which he rapped under the moniker, MC Ricky Fresh. A year later, he and the group would release “La Di Da Di”, a single that would skyrocket his and the Get Fresh Crew’s success.

However, it wasn’t until 1988 when he solidified himself as a solo artist when he released his debut album, The Great Adventures of Slick Rick. Featuring stand-out tracks such as “Children’s Story” and “Mona Lisa”, the album would go on to top the U.S. R&B album charts and be considered as an influential record to many.

He would later release three albums during the 1990s before ceasing to create new music and instead, expanding his ventures towards philanthropy and business. All in all, Rick has been considered one of hip hop’s most influential artists and his works have been praised, sampled, interpolated, and referenced by an extended assortment of artists.

songs.full_title: Children's Story by Slick Rick
songs.title: Children’s Story

description.plain:
“Children’s Story,” the second single released from The Great Adventures of Slick Rick, is the peak of Slick Rick’s storytelling in the form of a classic cautionary tale for children. He tells the story of two kids who decide to start robbing people. One of the kids becomes addicted and can’t stop. One day he robs an undercover detective. After a long chase with the cops, he is shot dead.

In Check the Technique, Slick Rick talked about “Children’s Story”:

We tried to make it a visual picture, especially with the ending. The ‘Knock 'em out the box, Rick,’ was like the climax, the big party part. We did the overlapping vocals because we wanted to keep the effect that was on [Doug E. Fresh’s] “The Show.” I saw that scene in real life, so I just put it on paper and added a little fiction to make it more interesting. I didn’t see the people get shot, but I saw the people go to jail and ruin their whole life.

“Children’s Story” peaked at #2 on Billboard’s Hot Rap Songs chart. The song’s concept has been covered by several artists and a number of lines have been sampled, mainly “Once upon a time not long ago” and “Knock ‘em out the box.” “Children’s Story” ranked at #61 on VH1’s list of the 100 Greatest Hip-Hop Songs.

songs.full_title: Behind Bars by Slick Rick
songs.title: Behind Bars

description.plain:
Slick Rick shot his cousin, Mark Plummer — who had previously been his bodyguard — and a bystander in 1990. He was indicted on two counts of attempted murder, and pled guilty to all charges. Those charges were


assault
use of a firearm
criminal possession of a weapon



Rick spent five years in prison, two for the then second degree attempted murder charges he received for the shooting, and three for his struggle with the INS. But, he was bailed out by Russell Simmons.

After being bailed out, Ricky D recorded his second album. The album received mixed reviews and the sales showed, that Rick’s popularity was on a downward spiral.

The third studio album, carrying the same name as this song, was released in 1994, while Rick was still in jail. This album was well-received, despite it having lower ratings than his debut.

Rick was released in 1996.

This song contains vocal samples from three songs; “Living for the City” by Stevie Wonder, “Top Billin'” by Audio Two, and “La Di Da Di” by Slick Rick & Doug E Fresh.

songs.full_title: Hey Young World by Slick Rick
songs.title: Hey Young World

description.plain:
“Hey Young World” is the third and final single released from Slick Rick’s classic debut album, The Great Adventures of Slick Rick. He’s telling the youth to show respect for themselves by also respecting their parents and education while staying on a straight and narrow path away from wrongdoers.

In Check the Technique, Rick talked about “Hey Young World”:

I wanted to put down a positive message with a reggae twist. It was a statement from my point of view. Seeing people going the wrong route and trying to explain to them that it’s not the route to go. I wasn’t trying to be too preachy.

“Hey Young World” peaked at #17 on Billboard’s Hot Rap Singles chart. The song has been sampled in various hip-hop and R&B songs and it helped inspire the Nas song “The World Is Yours.”

songs.full_title: Treat Her Like a Prostitute by Slick Rick
songs.title: Treat Her Like a Prostitute

description.plain:
In “Treat Her Like A Prostitute,” Slick Rick advises his male listeners to regard their sexual relationships with women as purely transactional, warning that committing to any other approach may leave them emotionally or financially vulnerable.  He offers three verses of anecdotal evidence to support his thesis.

In Check the Technique, Rick provided some background on the track:

It was something that me and Doug [E. Fresh] used to do, with [him on] the beatbox. We used to do it live and people used to just snap. The punchlines would always liven up a party. That was the only older song I did for the album. All the rest of them on there was new. That was like real-life experiences, and then making them humorous to a certain degree. I just figured that that was how it goes. It was more my outlook on life at the time. I wasn’t trying to be disrespectful to no good women.

songs.full_title: Teenage Love by Slick Rick
songs.title: Teenage Love

description.plain:
“Teenage Love” was released as the lead single for Slick Rick’s debut album The Great Adventures of Slick Rick. It was another “rap ballad” in the Def Jam catalog following LL Cool J’s hit “I Need Love,” which was released the previous year. The single peaked at #8 on Billboard’s Hot Rap Singles chart.

In Check the Technique, Rick talked about the creation of “Teenage Love”:

The version I myself had done for that song was a more dancey type of track—you could definitely dance to it more than listen to it. But they [the label and producers] envisioned doing it the way it came out. That song was just expressions of what I went through in high school. You know, getting my heart broken and all that type of stuff. The rap wasn’t written to follow the [LL Cool J] ‘I Need Love’ trend, but the music was done for that type of feel. I think it was a good idea to make it more of a ballad.

Known for their sample-heavy chaotic productions for Public Enemy, The Bomb Squad provided the melancholy track for Rick to tell his story. The music video featured cameos from Brooklyn residents Big Daddy Kane and a young Kimberly “Lil' Kim” Jones.

songs.full_title: The Ruler's Back by Slick Rick
songs.title: The Ruler’s Back

description.plain:
“The Ruler’s Back” signals Rick’s return to the rap game following his hiatus after his star-making performances on Doug E. Fresh’s classic 1985 singles “The Show” and “La-Di-Da-Di.” Run-DMC’s DJ Jam Master Jay provided the regal track around the time his group released their Tougher Than Leather album.

In Check the Technique, Rick provided some background about the track.

‘Teenage Love’ was the first song that we did for release as a single, but ‘The Ruler’s Back’ was actually out before it. I put it out there to [DJ] Red Alert on a cassette. It started to get so much play that the label got mad at me [laughs]. We had a version of the track that was a little more bouncy, but we didn’t get to drop that one.

Jay-Z paid homage to Slick Rick The Ruler with his own version of “The Ruler’s Back” from his 2001 album The Blueprint.

songs.full_title: The Moment I Feared by Slick Rick
songs.title: The Moment I Feared

description.plain:
The song is a cautionary tale of a young man who gets involved in less than reputable situations and the repercussions of living the street life.

In Check the Technique, Rick talked about “The Moment I Feared”:

 It was a story of me envisioning myself—you know how when you’re young you envision yourself being with the drug dealer’s girl. And you just imagine yourself falling into a story like that.

songs.full_title: Lick the Balls by Slick Rick
songs.title: Lick the Balls

description.plain:
Slick Rick and The Bomb Squad close out The Great Adventures of Slick Rick with the bouncy “Lick the Balls.” In Check the Technique, Rick talked about the track and working with The Bomb Squad:

That was supposed to be a little more aggressive. Talkin' shit. Braggadocious. I liked it to some degree. That was the one that Eric Sadler made that I thought wasn’t so bad. Bringing in Sadler and [Hank] Shocklee was the label’s thing—they decided they would make it a hot album. It was pretty smooth working with them, overall. I liked ‘Lick the Balls,’ but the rest of the stuff they did I wasn’t feeling as much.

songs.full_title: I Shouldn't Have Done It by Slick Rick
songs.title: I Shouldn’t Have Done It

description.plain: “I Shouldn’t Have Done It” was the first single released from Slick Rick’s second album, The Ruler’s Back. It was released on June 6, 1991, by Def Jam Recordings with production from Vance Wright and lyrics written by Slick Rick. It would be the most successful single from the album, being the only one of three singles to make it to the Billboard charts. It reached number fifty on the Hot R&B Singles chart and number two on the Hot Rap Singles chart.
